results.title: Kangaroos: faces in the mob
results.creator_credit: Glen Carruthers, Jan Aldenhoven and Green Cape Wildlife Films
results.brief_description: Award-winning filmmakers, Dr. Jan Aldenhoven and Glen Carruthers, spent two years working with a team of biologists to produce this engaging and stunningly photographed study of the lives of a mob of 60 Eastern Grey kangaroos in a NSW river valley. The biologists had been studying this mob continuously for fifteen years. Their studies have revealed the richly complex society of the mob. In the course of the year, we see everything from birth to the dramatic and sometimes deadly contests between the males. Winner of a Logie award for best documentary.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Glen Carruthers, Jan Aldenhoven and Green Cape Wildlife Films

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 2. Varieties [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and John Shaw
results.brief_description: Shows some of the variously adapted species of kangaroos in their natural environments: rat Kangaroos, quokkas, tree kangaroos, forest wallabies, rock wallabies and others. In Italian language.

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 2 [Italian version]
results.brief_description: Part Two examines various varieties of the Kangaroo, such as the Rat Kangaroo and the Quokkas. The manner in which the Kangaroo has been able to adapt its form to suit the peculiarities of a variety of environments is stressed. Some rare species are noted in the examination of the relationship between the animal and its habitat

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 1. Biography [Italian version]
results.brief_description: Part 1: Overviews the evolution of the Kangaroo, tracing its development over fifty species, from tree-dwellers to the better-known “Big Red”. The feeding, and mating habits of various species are examined, also birth and development in the pouch are studied

results.title: Kangaroos. Part 1. Biography [Italian version]
results.creator_credit: David Bairstow, John Shaw and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian Wildlife”.
Part one begins with the evolution of the kangaroo, tracing its development into over 50 species, from tree-dwellers to the better-known “big red”. The feeding, and mating habits of various species are examined, also birth and development in the pouch are studied. Narrated by Lionel Long. In Italian language.

results.title: Kangaroos
results.creator_credit: Langton Gould-Marks and Australian Instructional Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Wild Life”.
A study of the kangaroo as one of the oldest mammals in history. Describes other marsupials of similar type; discusses aspects of the male and female animal; explains how the young animal reaches the mother’s pouch after birth; mentions other types such as the paddy melon, the swamp wallaby, the pretty-faced wallaby and the tree kangaroo.
